title: Will Bashar al-Assad cease to be President of Syria before 1 March 2017?
preds: It is now Feb 28th, one day before the deadline of the question, and Bashar al-Assad is still the President of Syria
At this stage. Not a chance

Barring a jaw-dropping black swan, this question will close as a "No" in less than twelve hours. However, there is no Syrian state to speak of, and there is no Syrian nation, nor was there ever any hope of creating one. I wonder if a new iteration of this question will be posed by GJO, with a new terminal date - presumably some time in 2018. The answer to that question will be "No" too.

"The Obama administration tipped its hand early in the Syrian war when it called for regime change. Other governments in the region and the West joined the chorus, and the insistence on a "political transition" — which invariably meant Assad's ouster — became commonplace in international forums. But since Russia's 2015 military intervention on Assad's behalf, the Syrian president has gained the upper hand. His forces and allied militias control the country's key urban centers, while the constellation of rebel factions appears more divided and vulnerable than ever."

We're definitely in slip-in-the-bathtub territory here. Only a complete black swan will close this as a "Yes," and by definition black swans can't be foreseen. He won't be overthrown in the next two months, and the odds of his assassination are effectively zero. As for the rebels, there was never any rebel army, or rebel movement. The "rebels" have always been a collection of warlord militias that are as likely to fight each other as fight Assad. One exception is the Kurds, who have their own national ambitions which they will not risk pursuing a war against Assad. The other exception is ISIS, which is in no position to even undertake meaningful operations against regime territory, let alone actually threaten Assad.

The history of the Brute Squad:
First, it should be stressed that these two battalions are really quite unique units.  While formally they are just part of the larger Russian special forces community, they have a unique history and unique reputation.  Traditionally, Russia has always relied on elite Muslim shock forces, and most of those have been Chechen.  This was true before the 1917 Revolution as it was true after.  For example, the so-called “Muslim battalion” played a key role in the invasion of Afghanistan.  And 2008, the Chechen battalions “West” and “East” played a key role in the Russian counter-offensive against the Georgian forces.  To make a long story short: not only are these battalions known for their amazing courage and skills, their appearance often sends the opposing forces into a panic.

Assad will go by March 1 in three scenarios:
 - an outright military defeat - unlikely as things stand now. I put a 1% probability here. 
 - a political deal. This is, however, complicated. On the one hand, the external powers involved in Syria would love to have a deal that ends fighting and eliminates ISIS. I dare say  - and this is a big assumption - that for them to succeed, they should envisage a Lebanon-style power-sharing agreement rather than an Iraq-type majority-takes-all approach that's currently on the table. UNITED NATIONS Russia questioned on Tuesday a report by the United Nations and a global chemical weapons watchdog that blamed Syrian government forces for two chlorine gas attacks, saying the U.N. Security Council could not use the conclusions to impose sanctions.

ISW, SYRIA SITUATION REPORT: JULY 16 - 22, 2016: http://understandingwar.org/backgrounder/syria-situation-report-july-16-22-2016
"The failed coup attempt in Turkey on July 15 will generate significant upheaval in the Syrian Civil War. Turkish President Recep Erdogan will likely direct his attention inward over the coming months in order to purge his domestic rivals and consolidate his power. This distraction will likely disrupt the flow of material, financial, and intelligence support provided to opposition groups by Turkey, enabling short-term military gains by a number of actors including Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and the Islamic State of Iraq and al-Sham (ISIS). The Syrian Kurdish YPG may also exploit this moment in order to take further steps towards the establishment of an autonomous federal region along the Syrian-Turkish Border while Turkey remains incapable of mustering a coherent military response. At the same time, the ongoing political instability threatens the continued ability of the U.S.-led anti-ISIS coalition to conduct air operations out of Incirlik Airbase in Southern Turkey, presenting a complication to ongoing military efforts that could slow the current momentum against ISIS in Northern Syria. Over the long-term, the ongoing purges will likely allow Erdogan to remove the internal obstacles that prevented him from pursuing deeper intervention into the Syrian Civil War, including the provision of advanced weapons to the opposition or the establishment of a ‘safe zone’ along the border. Erdogan will likely augment these policies with expanded aid to Salafi-Jihadist groups such as Ahrar al-Sham that provide a support network for Al-Qaeda in Syria. The coup thus threatens to fuel the spread of radicalization and regional disorder."

Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs, June 20, 'Cracks in the Iran-Syria-Hizbullah-Russia Axis': http://jcpa.org/cracks-iran-syria-hizbullah-russia-axis/
Clips for JCPA article:
"In particular, Russia is leading an effort to formulate a new constitution for Syria. According to the Lebanese newspaper Al-Akhbar, which is affiliated with Hizbullah and usually reflects the view of its leadership, Russia is even framing main sections of this constitution. The newspaper claims to have in its possession a draft of the proposed constitution that includes comments written by the Syrian leadership. Assad, for his part, denies any such involvement. Already at the end of May 2016, Al-Akhbar published an initial report on the issue of Russia’s role in crafting the constitution.
Iran and Hizbullah are not happy about Russia’s stepped-up efforts to resolve the Syrian crisis. Despite the cooperation between Iran and Russia, which apparently is piloted by Qasem Soleimani, commander of the Quds Force of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps, they disagree more and more on Syria’s future once the crisis comes to an end.  This dispute also bedevils the Syrian regime (and Hizbullah), which finds itself between the Russian hammer and the Iranian anvil especially as the clashes escalate among the various forces and militias operating in different regions of Syria."

Comments: I'm going to drop 5 based on the deployment of the Iranian regular army. Keeping % on the high-side due to time left on this IFP and fully expect Gulf coalition to execute 'Plan B'. While Tehran's governing hardliners may voice undying commitment to al-Assad, this will cost IR in rials, materiel and higher KIA in the coming weeks and may prove unpopular at home. Iran's regular army is +60% conscripts, which may result in higher desertion rates and other force degradation. 
The Islamic Republic of Iran Army Ground Forces (Persian: نیروی زمینی ارتش جمهوری اسلامی ایران‎‎), acronymed NEZAJA (Persian: نزاجا‎‎) is the ground forces of the Islamic Republic of Iran Army.
In Iran, it is also called Artesh, (ارتش) which is Persian for "army." In 2007, the regular Iranian Army was estimated to have 350,000 personnel (220,000 conscripts and 130,000 professionals) plus around 350,000 reservists for a total of 700,000 soldiers according to the CSIS. Conscripts serve for 21 months and have professional military training.
Source: Wikipedia

Russian units continue to play an active role in Syria. From the WSJ: "Russia has been moving artillery units to areas of northern Syria where government forces have massed, raising U.S. concern the two allies may be preparing for a return to full-scale fighting as the current cease-fire falter." The potential breakdown of the ceasefire and continued Russian involvement in Syria makes it increasingly likely Assad will continue to hold onto power for the foreseeable future.

Russia pulling out of Syria is probably a good sign overall, indicating that US & Russia can work together in some capacity. Whether or not this means, behind close doors, they are working on a solution that involves the removal of Assad remains to be seen. I think, net, it probably slightly increases the chance Assad is removed peacefully, especially if US is willing to haggle Syria AND Ukraine w/ Russia at same time (which is leverage Russia may have gained with it's ME gambit). I think the chances of him being removed forcefully remain low, as Russia has shown that it's not willing to let that happen. So I'm bumping my forecast just a bit, due to the long remaining time period and the indication that some diplomatic solution may be slightly more likely.

I believe that Bashar al-Assad will not cease to be president of Syria before this date due to a number of different factors. For one, Syria is going through a major crisis with ISIS inhabiting a good chunk of the country. The International community cannot balance two conflicts in one country, and they are focusing on ISIS due to their crimes against humanity. It is fairly unlikely that this conflict will be resolved before that time. In addition, even if it was, Russia still provides Assad with weapons, which would give him some power.

He will likely remain in office because he has extreme control over a big portion of the Syrian government. He has noted that he would stay in office until terrorism has been eradicated, which doesn't seem likely by March 1, 2017 as ISIS continues to wreak havoc in the middle east.

A large factor in this is who the next president is. Until then, Obama is unlikely to take drastic steps to topple Al-Assad. If it were Donald Trump, who is planning to go along with Putin and mostly embrace isolationism, it is unlikely that al-Assad would be overthrown. However, other GOP candidates along with Hillary Clinton may favor more aggressive policies; however, it is unlikely that much would happen in so little time.

Due to a civil war in Syria and due to the lack of support for Bashar al-Assad by many of the world’s powers.  Russia, even though they are still supporting him militarily, said they are opposed to him and the United States are opposed.  With the support of the Russian military and the inability of the Syrian people to overthrow him, a change would have to occur from the United States or some other world power besides Russia.  I do not see that occurring unless al-Assad creates a truly heinous crime which I see as a possibility.

My prediction: 35%
Since al-Assad will step down because if the Civil war in Syria ends before March 2017 it will be very likely that he ceases to be president, but there is still a chance he will stay in presidency, and there is no guarantee that the war will end that soon. Also, there is a very small chance he would be killed in office because of the sheer amount of defense he has.

Upon reflection, I think that Assad's position has actually been improved at this point.  Russian support has degraded so-called moderate opposition, and cleared the field for ISIS and Nusra Front.  This has shaped the choice for Syria's future and made it much more difficult for any party attached to the position that "Assad must go."  If you could wave a magic wand and make Assad disappear today, essentially you would be surrendering the country to ISIS and Nusra Front.  Who would welcome that?  Putin has played a skillful game.  He has changed the situation on the ground to strengthen Assad's position.  Moreover, the Russians aren't really leaving anyway.  Go ahead.  Hold all the peace talks you want.  No one's going to agree to trade Assad for ISIS and Nusra Front.  Sorry about that.

- The chances of a dictator being ousted by a rebel force is low. 
- Rebels in Syria have been weakened by Assad, Putin, and Isis. 
- Assad is a strategic advantage for Isis because he keeps the US from getting a foothold in the upper levels of government in the region where Assad still controls. 
- Assad comes from a family with a history of violence and ruthlessness in the quest for maintaining control. 
- Nobody inside of the Assad regime has the recognition or credibility to govern, so an internal coup is very unlikely (less than 1-2%). 
- Assad has held on for 5 years of war. In other words, Assad has faced mortal threat for years but still holds on, albeit to a smaller stretch of land.

Assad seems to be in a reasonable position.  Despite the announced withdrawal of (some) Russian forces from Syria he is still being backed by Putin.  His regime is on a far more robust footing than six months ago, and a great deal would have to happen to see him fall from power.  It is worth considering the different plausible futures that might lead to Assad NOT being President on 1 March 2017, their likelihood and from there come up with a forecast of the chance of him staying in power.
I currently envision five scenarios (with the assumption Assad wants to remain President):
Accidental death or other severe impairment/illness that leads to his removal - remote (1%)
Internal coup / assassination - highly unlikely (4%)
Opposition / Daesh assassination of Assad - highly unlikely (10%)
Forced from power by Russia and/or Iran to facilitate a peace agreement in Syria - unlikely (15%) in the time frame
Still President on 1 March 2017 - likely (70%)

Is Assad becoming the Rodney Dangerfield of world leaders? Two days ago, his longtime BFF announced he's pulling out, part way, at least. Ides of March, hmmm.... Today, those darned Kurds have announced that they are setting up a federal district in northern Syria, making official what long had been a fact on the ground. Turkey's Ergodan not pleased. Russia's withdrawal means Assad has lost his latest ace in the hole.  Still think he'll hang on though, because external players (especially Iran) will probably prevent the rebels from gaining the upper hand militarily.  Assad's most likely path out is through a negotiated arrangement.  And I still haven't seen anything that makes me think that's about to happen.

The Russian announcement is a bit odd in view of the successful attack this weekend by Nusra Front against the 13th Division, a rebel group that has received U.S. weaponry including anti-tank missiles.  Nusra Front and Islamic State share the distinction of being excluded from the cease-fire agreement and any political settlement.  Seeing Nusra Front on the move, raises questions about the Russian announcement and what it really can mean.  With this action, Nusra Front now controls Maaret al Numan which is right on the border of Assad's home territory.  Putin might have good reasons to be looking for an exit strategy (weak economy at home, costly military quagmire, trouble with Turkey, etc).   Maybe he hopes he can drop the Syrian tar baby on the table at the so-called peace talks, and just walk away.  Nusra Front and Islamic State seem to have other ideas.  The Russians may be about to find out how difficult their exit strategy will be to execute.  I think they will have to stick around.  Nevertheless, Assad's grip on power might be just a little weaker in the wake of these developments.  I'm upping my forecast slightly.

Interesting announcement by Putin, especially on the heels of the recent Iranian announcement of its withdrawal of most of its support. Now we see 1) does Iran come back to fill the gap, and re-establish its position as Assad's main outside sponsor? (My guess: not any time soon); 2) since the Russian withdrawal is only "partial" who stays?  (My guess: ground crews and air command and control units. Perhaps also some aircraft left behind for the Syrian Air Force.) 3) what will be the reaction of Turkey now that there's a decreased risk of direct confrontation with Russia? (No guess on this one.)

A partial “cessation of hostilities” has created just enough space for a UN-sponsored meeting in Geneva today. Both Russia and America have had to give the sides they support a firm push to get them to the table. The opposition umbrella group, the so-called High Negotiations Committee, says that the talks should concentrate on securing a timetable for a political transition. But the regime of Bashar al-Assad has no interest in such a process. It has offered “elections” that would exclude all groups it defines as “terrorists”: ie, just about anybody who opposes Mr Assad. The rebels believe the regime’s real aim is to lock in recent military gains secured thanks to Russian air power. Plenty of fighting is still going on. Mr Assad’s forces and the Russians are pounding Islamic State positions around Palmyra. IS and Syria’s al-Qaeda franchise, Jabhat al-Nusra, are specifically excluded from the fragile truce
[From The Economist Espresso]

Assad could basically leave power in these ways:
- ISIS conquering Syria. Practically impossible; they got their nose bloodied by the Kurds already, and won't stand much of a chance fighting an offensive campaign against an organized army. <5%
- NATO powers deposing Assad. Possible, but unlikely before ISIS is defeated or at least pushed out of Syria, which may well take longer than a year. Until then, Assad is a useful tyrant, and western states almost never topple those. ~20%
- A successful revolution in Syria by one of the other players in the civil war. Very unlikely without foreign support (which itself is very unlikely before ISIS is defeated, and somewhat unlikely even after); on their own, they didn't even come close until now. Plus, as long as ISIS is at large, nobody will show much interest in Assad's human rights violations, giving him more options to crack down on internal opposition. ~5%
- Accident, assassination, health reasons, etc. Does happen, but very rarely. <5%

Assad could be driven out of Syria but this seems unlikely while he is being supported by Russia and Iran who would lose face with this outcome (so a 10% chance). Putin has just said that Assad could be given asylum in Russia if he was rejected by the Syrian people in an election (so Putin has presumably considered the possibility and is maybe trying to see how the idea flies) but in order to have a real election a cease fire would be needed and its difficult to see how an election could be held in territory controlled by IS or other Islamic group who do not believe in the concept of democracy. So on the face of it Putin's idea does not seem to have any possibility of happening. However Putin does not say things without a reason, so the question is why did Putin mention elections at all? It could be that Putin has realised that his airpower is not going to win the war for Assad. If so the options are for Iran to send in large numbers of ground troops (which would upset the Sunni states and US), or Russia to send in a lot of ground troops, which could see Russia bogged down in an unwinnable war similar to what happened in Afghanistan in the 1980s or for some way be found so that Russia and Iran can get out of Syria without loss of face. A "peace" plan/cease fire with Assad "retiring" and some other figurehead taking over the Syrian government could be proposed. (A bit like the way that the US got out of Vietnam). Even this scenario is difficult to pull off as there is no sign of all parties being willing to talk, but Assad "retiring" could be seen as a concession. So there is maybe a 25% change that Putin will get Assad to "retire" in the next 14 months. (10% + 25% = 35%)

Lest we close out the year thinking that we have no analyst who understands Syria - one recently answered a query by referring me to the link below (no doubt cuz she helped write it) but at the same time it confirms that inter agency cooperation and compounding of effort are dead in D.C. Today.
 ‘The Joint Chiefs believed that Assad should not be replaced by fundamentalists. The administration’s policy was contradictory. They wanted Assad to go but the opposition was dominated by extremists. So who was going to replace him? To say Assad’s got to go is fine, but if you follow that through – therefore anyone is better. It’s the “anybody else is better” issue that the JCS had with Obama’s policy.’ The Joint Chiefs felt that a direct challenge to Obama’s policy would have ‘had a zero chance of success’. So in the autumn of 2013 they decided to take steps against the extremists without going through political channels, by providing US intelligence to the militaries of other nations, on the understanding that it would be passed on to the Syrian army and used against the common enemy, Jabhat al-Nusra and Islamic State.
http://www.lrb.co.uk/v38/n01/seymour-m-hersh/military-to-military
 ‘We weren’t intent on deviating from Obama’s stated policies,’ the adviser said. ‘But sharing our assessments via the military-to-military relationships with other countries could prove productive. It was clear that Assad needed better tactical intelligence and operational advice. The JCS concluded that if those needs were met, the overall fight against Islamist terrorism would be enhanced. Obama didn’t know, but Obama doesn’t know what the JCS does in every circumstance and that’s true of all presidents.’

Updated forecast (downward): 
The UN Security Council resolution seems like a step forward. Yet, as indicated by the participants, many obstacles remain. Given that the resolution avoids the question of Assad’s fate, it appears to confirm earlier statements that he will remain in power for the immediate future. As indicated in my first forecast, any political settlement hinges on the timing and sequencing of key events. In this case, those events include a military cease-fire (meaning Syria’s opposition groups and Assad’s forces). If the cease-fire holds, then the process of putting together a political settlement begins. The very last phase would include elections and a transition. The answer to the question of whether Assad surrenders power before March 2017 is analogous to an international relations rubik’s cube – there are many permutations. Based on recent diplomatic activity, the probability of Assad remaining in power for the foreseeable future seems more likely.

The Russians and Iranians want influence over Syria, military bases (and for Iran the ability to transit weapons and material to Lebanon).  They don't have any particular loyalty to Assad himself.   If government forces in Syria are able to re-establish control, then Assad becomes a liability (both Syrians and the international community will be happier if he leaves and that could be the price of letting Russia and Iran control Syria).   The Russians can build him a nice dacha on the Crimean coast.   If the government forces lose more control and things get uglier, Assad will be the fall guy.  Either way I don't think he serves any useful purpose in the end game (though as a matter of principle the Russians and Iranians will want to keep him in the seat until the end game arrives or an alternative candidate is identified).  They will find one- money buys loyalty and the threat of Iranian/Russian reprisals against a turncoat will keep the candidate on the straight and narrow.  For me the main question is whether the "end game" will come by 1 March 2017.    I see an 80% chance it will, and an 80% chance that Assad is gone in that instance (hence 64%).

There's a lot to say about the UN resolution, but I'm sure everyone has read it and has an opinion about its content. I think perhaps the most important thing is that the resolution permits "offensive and defensive" operations against al-Nusra, ISIS and other "terrorists" not party to the negotiations. The full list of unacceptable "terrorist" groups has not yet been finalized. Some rebel groups (presumably including militias) say they will not participate in the negotiations unless they have a timetable for Assad stepping down. There is no word if these groups will abide by the ceasefire.

- The three methods in which this could get resolved are: a deal (scenario A), an assassination (B), a military defeat (C)
- Let's handle each of these separately.

Russia seems to be already warming up to the idea of a coalition gov't in Syria comprised of elements of Assad regime and elements of Free Syrian Army. To me the question with Assad hinges on what exactly is Russia's top priority to preserve in such a scenario. I believe that would be maintenance of their military installations in Syria with Russia as air security guarantor and favored status for Russia/ exclusion of Turk influence with any new coalition gov't. I still believe Putin will in the end offer Assad as a bargaining chip for such a result. Whether the rebels will accept such a Russian role is questionable, but perhaps if US makes it clear that's their last chance before NATO grows wary and leaves. The latest from Riyadh below. Highlight: no role for Assad or his top lieutenants, which pretty much puts the kibosh on the whole idea of a regime-rebel peace conference right there. Your initial negotiating position should always be more than your willing to settle for, but it can't be that your interlocutor should ultimately give you everything you want and then go away, or put himself at your mercy. This also kind of obviates the possibility of Russia or Iran getting rid of Assad and installing someone else. The Russians and Iranians would have to scour Syria (and Assad's prisons) to find a Syrian Konrad Adenauer, and even assuming such a person exists, he would have to be accepted by the regime supporters and the rebels. The reports out of Riyadh make it clear that the rebels are not fighting Assad personally, but the regime. They would consider the replacement of Assad strictly a cosmetic change. So the presence of Assad is not the impediment to peace, and never has been. The impediment to peace is that the factions in Syria have incompatible visions that do not lend themselves to a negotiated settlement. Even if Assad were eliminated, the regime would survive. Even if the regime were eliminated, the incompatible aims of the remaining factions would still not be reconciled.

A Kurdish-Arab coalition fighting the Islamic State in northern Syria has announced the formation of a political arm, AFP reported 10DEC15. Representatives presented the Syrian Democratic Council at a conference in the town of al-Malikiyah as the new political wing of the U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces, a coalition made up of the Kurdish People's Protection Units (YPG) and smaller Arab and Christian militias. Participants at the conference said the group's goals include a new constitution and a decentralized political system for Syria, such as the ones that the YPG has initiated in the EAST. The group also emphasized the importance of "working with Syria's government to end the conflict", a course of action strongly rejected by another collection of opposition and rebel groups currently meeting in Riyadh.  :D

The most likely, and probably worst, outcome is that Russia and Iran, and possibly one or more other players, will select different guys to take over Syria. Somebody in the melee will kill or imprison Assad, or he'll catch on and leave town, or somebody who still feels kindly toward him will offer him a comfy retirement.  The war will go on and on and on and on, but this Q will be a Yes. March 2017 is a long way off, and the war will grind everybody down. Events in any two or three or nine days are unlikely to determine the outcome, except in an additive sort of way.

Since the Saudis are going to try to forge a rebel negotiating front starting next week, and regime-rebel talks are supposed to begin in January, I think it's worth it to look back at these two articles from September and October. Both propose the Bosnian settlement as a solution, and I think such a solution may result from the talks - assuming the talks do not break down or indefinitely stall. Notice that the Dayton Accord included the signature, and required the acceptance, of Slobodan Milosevic, who was considered the Assad of his day. Milosevic was ultimately overthrown, but by a domestic uprising, not by outside military action. If next year political leaders and foreign ministers start talking about Bosnia as a precedent for Syria, I think we can expect one of two things: everyone will hold their nose and Assad will be a party to any settlement, or the possibility of a settlement that includes Assad will cause the rebels to abandon the negotiations. Updated Forecast: Based on an absence of momentum toward a political transition, a minor adjustment of my original forecast is necessary (30%).  With no advancement toward a political transition, the souring of relations between Russia and Turkey, and the focus on ISIS over Assad, the probability of an Assad-free Syria by March 2017 appears even less likely.  
Interestingly, Deputy Secretary of State Tony Blinken provided an optimistic assessment of the civil war this week (1 December), stating that the chances of a political transition in Syria were better than "at any time during this crisis."  See: http://foreignpolicy.com/2015/12/01/top-u-s-diplomat-political-solution-to-syria-civil-war-now-in-sight/
As you read this article, you'll notice that for Blinken to be correct, his (possibly the State Department's as well) assessment of the Russian position in the conflict must be accurate. Over the last 20 years (at least), the U.S. has a poor record of calibrating its diplomacy with Russian interests. With all due respect to Secretary Blinken, I don't believe we are turning the corner in Syria any time soon.

Turkey's downing of a Russian warplane did, at least in the current time frame, firm up IR and RU support for al-Assad. I believe how long that support lasts are influenced by several variables:
- Syrian Army. So far, their performance can be deemed mixed; gaining in some areas, losing in others. Their success can be summed up in a few words: Russian air support. Iranian and Hezbollah fighters. Negatives to consider: war-fatigue and demoralization (they've been fighting for almost 5 years), shrinking manpower pool; motivated opposition (Kurds, ISIS). It's not hard to see that, without the Army, al-Assad would have been road-kill a long time ago. 
- Iran. From an increasingly wide array of sources there seems to be a consensus building that the removal of Assad from power has ceased to be the strong priority it once was. The rebel factions fighting on the ground who continue to make Assad their priority may find themselves ever more isolated in their pursuit as the emphasis shifts to ISIS, lowering the probability that their effort would be successful. Finally, the incident between Russia and Turkey throws a wrench into an already wrench filled diplomacy. Adjusting accordingly.

I'm raising the odds of Assad's exit -- a little.  Assad has a strong will to remain in power, firm backing from his political constituency, and Russian support.  This will help him resist.  However, forces that believe Assad's departure is required for a political settlement, now believe they have a chance to turn Russia and change the situation.  Unfortunately, the political realities of factions and forces within Syria will continue to make this difficult.  Excessive focus on Assad's departure fails to address the legitimate existential concerns of his constituency.   Excessive focus on destruction of ISIS, also fails to acknowledge the absence of any credible government succession option.  Beyond that, Putin is no pushover.  Today he called the downing of a Russian jet, "a stab in the back" by forces who support terrorism.

If Assad were to go right now, what would happen? No matter the circumstances of his exit, I think we'd see Baghdad after Hussein all over again: a violent free-for all likely to work toward the benefit of ISIS.  I think the assorted non-ISIS rebel groups are going to get the worst of this, but we are not going to see a shift in things until they are subdued. Everybody with guns in the region wants to see a stable Syria, but each has a different version of that vision and none can move toward their version while the rebels are taking potshots at them. So, for the time being, Assad is the least bad choice of Iraq, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Russia and they all know it. (It's the least bad choice of the US, too, but we don't seem to be willing to acknowledge that.)

Not changing my forecast for now, but the link below is suggestive. It details one of the measures taken by the regime to alleviate its desperate manpower shortage. I consider this to directly affect the resolution of this question, since it appears that even without any increased pressure in the area, Assad is having trouble replacing losses in Damascus. According to the story, "Volunteers will supplement or replace regular army personnel at checkpoints and perform other primarily defensive roles." Which means that trained troops are in too short supply to waste them on more-or-less routine duties. This manpower shortage may not mean the end of the war - in my opinion it will not - but for purposes of the question, Assad's possession of Damascus is a condition of his remaining president. From what I've read, this story reflects a trend, and it could well be an indication that the question will close as "Yes" rather sooner than the end of the time frame.

Considering the meeting in Vienna had all Western parties coming to a very rough & vague idea of a plan (http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2015/11/14/vienna_talks_negotiators_agree_to_syria_peace_road_map_in_the_wake_of_paris.html), it's still important to note that Assad maintains Russian & iranian support. Both of these have powerful interests in maintaining Assad in a leadership role. While there may be "negotiations" over a "transition," what role Assad wil have in those and in any transition remains carefully unspoken. Then there is the further difficulty of finding "moderate" parties to engage in the "negotiations" who would be acceptable to all the Western powers, as well as to Russian & Iranian tastes.  So the possibility of these negotiations happening at all seem impractical at the moment. Russia will not agree to any negotiation or transition that lessens its role, interests or presence there & if they manage the situation to keep Assad in place he will owe them big time, even if the presidency ends up being a reduced position. So the Russians will likely seek to make as many cosmetic changes in any transition as it takes to placate the Western powers but will not toss their Assad, their guy. It's much more rational for them to keep him in place and collect on the favor. in light of the Vienna agreement, I moved up to a 30% Yes, but doubt much will come of the Vienna agreement, due to the difficulty of finding "moderates," the power of Russian & Iranian interests, and the fact that no Syrian factions were part of the Vienna meeting.

A Russian proposal to end Syria's conflict that would include early presidential elections faced opposition from both sides on Wednesday, as deep divisions remained over the fate of President Bashar Assad.
Syrian legislator Sharif Shehadeh, a member of the ruling Baath party, told The Associated Press there will be no presidential vote before Assad's latest term ends in 2021. He added that parliamentary elections are an internal Syrian affair and that it was still too early to hold them.
His comments came a day after Russia circulated a document on ending Syria's conflict that calls for drafting a new constitution within 18 months. The charter would be put to a popular referendum and then followed by an early presidential election.

I fail to see any particular significance in the new Russian proposal. As the BBC article points out, much of it is just a retread of the Geneva communique of three years ago. The BBC piece also details many of the obstacles to any peace plan. I consider the Russian proposal to be so much boilerplate. None of it has any immediate significance, nor is it intended to. In my opinion, Russia's proposal, and all Russian public statements so far, have two specific goals: first, to delegitimize any rebel groups that Russia wants to marginalize, perhaps giving Russia a chance to co-opt some rebel groups, and second, to legitimize the idea of Assad remaining in power, even if that power is tightly constrained.

International actors could step up efforts to force Assad to leave and any indication of this, or the falsification of the assumptions above, would prompt a revision of the forecast.

At the initial talks in Vienna on Oct. 30, the U.S., Russia, Iran and more than a dozen other nations agreed to launch a new peace effort involving Syria's government and opposition groups. But they carefully avoided the issue of when Assad might leave power â€” a dispute at the heart of the nearly five-year-old conflict that has claimed more than 250,000 lives.
British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond said there is "quite a lot going on" behind the scenes ahead of this weekend's talks, and U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry "is highly active in trying to promote this process." But Hammond stressed to reporters at U.N. headquarters in New York that no one should underestimate "the scale of the challenge."
Hammond cited the "fundamental difference" between Britain, the U.S. and other countries that believe Assad must leave office as part of the transition process, and Syrian allies Russia and Iran "who believe that he should be able to take part in a future election and if that election decides that he should go, then he goes at that point.

There was an interesting exchange between American Senator Lindsay Graham (who was showboating for his Presidential bid) and a number of key administration players on the Syria file during one of those endless House committees recently. Graham was trying to develop a sound bite about Obama's policy on equipping fighters to fight not ISIL, but the combined Assad group of Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah. He was pressing for details on a possible shift of strategy away from taking down Assad, the prior held strategy. Not one administration representative would answer, because if they did confirm that the fight to remove Assad remains the objective, Graham would have teed up his sound bite, "in which case we are going to war with Russia and Iran by proxy in Syria". Which would be obvious. It was clear to me that the administration fully understands that any new effort at equipping rebels for anything but a fight against ISIL would indeed be just that proxy war.

There seems to be a growing consensus among the key players that a negotiated settlement to the Syrian civil war is needed before Assad steps down from power.  In this scenario, Assad remains in power until a negotiated settlement with opposition forces is reached. At that time, the various powers involved seem to be signaling Assad should go within 6 months. At some point, a transitional government enters the scene. Of course, many questions and challenges remain. For one thing, a negotiated settlement implies a cessation of violence. It is not necessary for all fighting to stop – as ISIS will likely never agree to any settlement. However, a cessation of violence between Syrian opposition forces and Assad’s military is required. The next question is who is doing the negotiating on behalf of rebel forces? These challenges are Syrian-specific. The intricacies of the diplomatic power struggle over the Syrian Civil war represents another layer of uncertainty: Russian intervention, Saudi Arabia/Iranian tensions, US/Russia tensions, US/Iranian tensions, Turkey, the E.U. and the refugee crisis, Jordan, and the UAE. It’s a hornets nest to say the least.  According to recent news sources, John Kerry indicated that Assad should go at some point, but talks must continue. In addition, today’s (30 October) WSJ reported that:

Still holding at 30%, and even that is only because of the condition that Assad not be driven from Damascus for more then three weeks. I don't think the Vienna talks have any significance at all at this time. Some news stories have highlighted indications that neither Russia or Iran is "wedded" to the idea of Assad remaining indefinitely. Of course they're not. Neither one of them is supporting him as a favor to him. They are doing it because the consider it to be to their advantage. Iran wants hegemony over as much of the Middle East as it can get, and Russia wants the ability to project power into the eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East. It's worth noting that the objectives of Russia and Iran are not really compatible, but they'll both worry about that later.

It seems that, as of late, many of the groups who once felt it to be an attainable goal to remove Assad are now undergoing a re-think of that possibility. Why is that? It may be that they never believed that was possible (or desirable) in the first place and were  staking out political or negotiating positions, or it could be that they have simply changed their mind in view of the changing nature of the issue and other players. Regardless, for public consumption at least, the drive to remove Assad by international fiat seems to have ended. I believe this matters as it reduces the list of ways Assad could leave considerably, and with them, the probability of his leaving as well. So...adjustment.

Initial Thoughts (26/10/2015): Barring assassination (which is unlikely if claims of Russian Special Ops Diplomatic Protection personnel deploying to Syria are true), I expect continued Russian involvement to increase the probability that Assad will remain as President. Russia needs military and logistical experience in the Middle East, so they will manage to stay and fight despite recession and sanctions at home and equipment problems. Russian offers to the FSA rebels is for show, but to their favor if the rebels agreed to it. Likewise, Assad's acquiescence to elections are window-dressing as they are predicated on the conditions that won't happen or would guarantee his victory (voting limitations). The US won't oppose Russian operations because it: 1) gives Russia a chance to fail spectacularly; 2) achieves many of the US's goals; 3) opens opportunities for US-Russian cooperation (public or secret) that could thaw relations with benefits elsewhere, and; 4) would affect the US election cycle in a way detrimental to the current Executive's party. Actions taken by the US would require a new party to win the Executive, but the window of action from inauguration to the expiration date of this question is too short to effect the cessation of Assad's regime.

Leaning towards departure from government for Assad. Putin's likely path to gain on the world stage is to regain his country's awareness and preference position, both economically and politically, from the G7. This is important for him as Russia suffers huge trade deficits with Europe and investments from other nations worldwide. Putin wants to take Russia back to the glory days when there was a USSR when it was a strong world power acting as a balance to that of the United States. At the same time he sees that Russia's power has been weakened from the days of the USSR. Putin needs the economic and political non-interference of the "West" to overcome the problems within Russia. He extends an Olive branch by joining fight against ISIS (even if it appears that its hard for the "West" to verify his results in this regard. Let's remember that a country's true agenda can often be cloaked in policy and actions that appear to contradict what a country states are their intentions on a world stage. He will find a way to get Assad out with dignity. He will then trade this capital to gain what he needs from the "West".  This will fix the refugee crisis and control or reduce the strength of ISIL significantly, both of which the "West" have as goals. He has to tred carefully to accomplish this because of economic and political alignment with Iran and other Islamic States.

The geopolitical complexities and hostilities that recent Russian activity in Syria is causing could potentially lead to Russia's eventual support of a political transition in Syria.  This would have the dual effect of legitimizing Russia's geopolitical strategy in the area, (Russia's critics would be largely appeased, since the general sentiment in the world, towards Russia, would be "Russia did what the US had been trying to do for years yet had failed to do: eradicate ISIS AND affect regime change") and giving their military presence and campaign in Syria geopolitical clout.  It is unlikely, though, that Russia would support an election to find a replacement, and is instead more likely to support an presidentially-appointed successor to Assad.  In this scenario, Russia would/could convince Assad that resignation in this manner was in his best interest, as it would allow Assad to live a relatively comfortable life post-Presidency, free from being pursued for criminal charges by the ICC, and such a move would give Russia the political capital to play a big role in the choosing of a replacement to Assad, primarily, one who is largely pro-Russian, something which would be vital to Russia's geopolitical strategy.

Here is how I break that question down:
I envision 3 main ways for him to cease to be the President of Syria:
1) His death - Bashar al-Assad is relatively young, having just turned 50, which makes his death by natural causes relatively unlikely. He could also die from an accident (as happened to his elder brother), or he could be the victim of an assassination. None of those possibilities seem likely.
2) His resignation/deposition while the Ba'ath Party stays in power. Again, not very likely.
3) The Syrian Civil War ends with rebels overthrowing the government. Seems the more likely of the three scenarios. However, the war has already lasted almost 5 years and doesn't seem to be clearly moving towards the end. For that reason, I think it is more likely that the rebels are not going to be able to seize power until March 2017.

I'm holding my forecast at 30%, where it's been all along. I interpret the trip as a message to Iran that Russia is now the dominant power in Syria, and Assad's survival no longer depends on Iran. Now, Iran is the junior partner to Russia, and Putin calls the shots. When Assad calls for a comprehensive peace including all the ethnic and religious groups in Syria, we have to remember that he's from a minority himself. I think what he's doing is offering himself as an anti-ISIS rallying point. If you are a Christian, Druze, or Shiite, or even a Sunni who dreads rule by ISIS, Assad starts to look pretty good. The Financial Times map shows ISIS controlling two enclaves inside Lebanon, and "support" along a wide area separating Homs-Hama-Latakia from Damascus. It also shows ISIS support along a road leading to an area south of Damascus, and an area of ISIS control southeast of the city itself. The NYT map shows an ISIS controlled enclave butting up against northeast Lebanon, and a rebel presence in and around Damascus. This is important because according to the administrators of GJP, if Assad is driven from Damascus for six weeks straight, the answer to the question is "Yes." Lately there's been talk of rebel groups coalescing in the face of Russian air strikes and intervention by Iranian army formations. I think it's possible that the rebels may be able to take and hold Damascus for a period of time during the next year and a half, especially if the maps are accurate and reflect actual military power and territorial control of ISIS and other rebel groups. 
I think everyone has made very reasoned arguments defending their positions, and those people who give "Yes" a zero per cent chance are probably correct. Bashar Assad will probably still be in power on March 1, 2017, and will still be styled "President of the Arab Republic of Syria." Assad may be assassinated or overthrown with or without the connivance of his sponsors, although for the moment I consider any such scenario unlikely. But the real question we 're forecasting here is, "Will Bashar Assad absent himself from Damascus for a period of at least six weeks before 1 March 2017." I think there's a pretty good chance that he will have to. I apologize for bringing this up a second time over the course of the past week. I promise this is the last time.

Assad is now supported by a major power whose government is determined to make his survival a test case of that power's ability to assert its influence in the Middle East. Were Assad to fall, Putin's prestige at home and Russia's influence abroad would both decline sharply. Putin and the Russian security establishment cannot permit such an outcome. To that end, they will use every tool at their disposal - from missiles to bombers to "volunteer" commandos, disinformation and lies, and worse.
Another reason that Assad will survive is that, even in the presence of a well-organized and well-supported insurgency,  regimes in the modern era typically hold up at least a decade before falling. Most insurgencies, including successful ones, take a generation to achieve their aims.  The Syrian insurgency is less than five years old. It is fragmented, poorly-supplied, and in want of a clear, charismatic, forceful leader. Expecting this haphazard crew to topple Assad, given the weight that Russia places on his survival , within the next 18 months is akin to expecting the Democratics to sweep the House races in the South in November 2016.

There are two plausible scenarios that would lead to Assad leaving power: military defeat by a rebel group or alliance of groups; or a negotiated transfer of power to a successor acceptable to both the current government's supporters and to anti-Assad rebels, in exchange for a ceasefire. The former scenario seems very unlikely (~5%) given recent Russian intervention in Syria, which appears to indicate a resolve to keep Assad in power as a useful Middle Eastern ally. The latter scenario is also  rather unlikely (~5%), as a 'peace process' settlement would need to be acceptable to both anti-Assad and pro-Assad groupings, and it is difficult to see what form of compromise could do this. Therefore, I do not think there is any more than a 10% likelihood of Assad leaving power in the given timespan.

I believe Russian (and Iranian) support had bought al-Assad SOME time.
These are the facts as I see it:
- Al-Assad's government control less than 15% of Syria.
- The Syrian economy and military are in bad shape (I don't think they're capable of recapturing more than 30 - 35% of the country even with Russian help).
- A healthy % of the Syrian population (news reports say a lot of draft-age men and even some of al-Assad supporters) continue to flee the turmoil. 
- Saudi Arabia (leading an alliance of Gulf states) has flat-out stated that al-Assad needs to go. 
- Putin and the Saudi defense minister apparently agree to common goals regarding Syria, but I don't think that'll change Saudi minds on al-Assad.
- RU is still fighting a war in UKR. Involvement in two military ventures (+ a weak economy) has to be a drain on the Russian treasury. How long can Putin commit?  
Affirming forecast.

There is too much strategic incoherence around removing Assad, and it is getting ever more incoherent.  IS is not necessarily focussed on his removal. Russia is strongly committed to his survival, as is Iran and Hezbollah. He also enjoys strong support from the minorities in western Syria - many of whom believe that if the regime falls they will face genocide. The US is becoming much more ambivalent about his departure. IS will remain the priority for the US and Russia.  The insurgent forces that are more focussed on opposing him are comparatively weak. There is no clear picture of what will happen if he goes or if the remaining structures of government will collapse if he does, leaving the rest of Syria in anarchy.

Russian intervention in the region means that this is unlikely to happen. Russia needs Tartus as a warm water port, access to Syria as an ally and trade partner, and international prestige as taking action against ISIS. They also tend to ignore blatant abuses of a government against its own citizens when no one else will. The US coalition is not going to take action against Assad because there is no credible alternate leader, "our" trained rebels failed miserably on their first mission and cannot be raised in sufficient numbers to make a difference, and there is too much risk of accidentally killing Russian personnel embedded with Syrian forces. While I doubt that Russian support will turn the tide, it certainly will help hold the line and ensure that the Latakia/Homs/Damascus belt with the majority of the Syrian population remains under regime control.

The recent influx of Russian troops into the Syrian conflict, suggests that Russia will not allow al-Assads regime to fall. As long as Russia continues to back al-Assad he, or at least his regime will remain in power. Should this support cease, the likelihood of him being removed from power will dramatically increase. 
From a U.S. perspective, it is likely that the fight against ISIS will take precedence over removing al-Assad from power. Taking into consideration the protracted nature of the civil war, al-Assad only need to keep holding on, while the opposition needs to win. 
It is also a possibility that Syria, in its current form, will not exist, begging a follow up question of what exactly al-Assad is president of. 
Caveat; al-Assad may yet be killed or captured.

Dateline 9-13-15 Russia is sending signals to the U.S. and Saudi Arabia that it may allow Syria’s embattled leader Bashar al-Assad to be eased out of power as it seeks to forge a united front against Islamic State and retain influence in the region, officials and Syrian opposition leaders said.
Officials from the three countries, as well as from the opposition, have been negotiating possible terms for sidelining Assad since at least June, when President Vladimir Putin hosted Saudi King Salman’s son, Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed, they said. Saudi Arabia is Assad’s main regional enemy, while Russia is his longtime ally. Since then, Russia’s whirlwind diplomacy has brought key officials from across the region to Moscow for talks. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-13/putin-said-to-explore-sidelining-assad-even-as-russia-arms-him

That's a long time when people are really, really committed to trying to kill you, though militarily it seems hard to imagine a total collapse.
Assad's friends are increasing support while his enemies are floundering.

I really think the West's appetite for regime change has soured after the outcomes of the past decade or so, thus I think it will be internally driven. Dictators tend to be resilient, but they are not invincible, and 18 months gives a lot of time for something unexpected to happen.

Bashar al-Assad has been struggling to hold on to power for a while now.  Even he has admitted that some regions must be abandoned in order to maintain control of others.  It is only a matter of time before he loses control of these regions as well, especially now that Turkey is involved in the conflict (recall that Turkey has been opposed to the Assad regime since the beginning).  Thus, it is unlikely that Assad remains in control for the next 19 months.  And if by some chance he manages to do so, it will not be as president of Syria as united nation.

Predictions of Assad's demise have been bouncing around for a couple of years now. None have come true yet. Couple factors worth considering: 

(1) The chance Assad will be killed by rebels is fairly small. Though rebels have managed to pick off a couple of high level generals over the past four years, Assad's security has held up thus far. 
(2) A military coup is possible, but Syria's Alawite community is fairly tightly bound to Assad. 
(3) All attempts to negotiate a settlement leading to Assad's peaceful departure have failed thus far. Momentum would likely have to turn strongly against Assad for him to consider such an option. 
(4) It is also unlikely that Assad will flee, as it would expose him to prosecution for war crimes, though a couple of countries have hinted at offering him protection (Iran, Russia, etc).
(5) Natural death or mental incapacitation is also unlikely, as Assad is only 49 years old and he isn't reported to be suffering from any type of serious medical conditions.  
(6) As this piece from the WP points out (http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/10/23/political-science-says-syrias-civil-war-will-probably-last-at-least-another-decade/), the average civil war lasts over 10-years. We are only 4-years into the Syrian one. It would be relatively abnormal for the war to come to a quick close in the near future.  
(7) Most external powers are more focused on ISIS than Assad at the moment. As ISIS the most organized and well equipped of Assad's challengers, this increases his odds of survival.

More entities want Assad gone than to stay. This includes ISIS and the US. There isn't a stable dictatorship and at this point there doesn't appear to be any political solutions on the table.
Syria is a distaster, and Bashar al-Assads leadership is much of the reason. 2017 is a long way off. At this point, I give better than even odds he won't last that long.
